author: MIKE GROSS | Sports Writer
title: Stormers take another gut-punch from York, lose 4-3 in 12 innings | Lancaster Barnstormers | lancasteronline.com
text: July 25, 2024 71° Close Buy Now Stormers third baseman Trace Loehr (6) gets the FerryHawks Luis Castro (6) to end the first inning of an Atlantic League baseball game at Clipper Magazine Stadium in Lancaster on Thursday June 27, 2024. CHRIS KNIGHT | Staff Photographer Facebook Twitter WhatsApp SMS Email Print Copy article link Stormers take another gut-punch from York, lose 4-3 in 12 innings MIKE GROSS | Sports Writer Jul 25, 2024 13 mins ago Facebook Twitter WhatsApp SMS Email Buy Now Stormers third baseman Trace Loehr (6) gets the FerryHawks Luis Castro (6) to end the first inning of an Atlantic League baseball game at Clipper Magazine Stadium in Lancaster on Thursday June 27, 2024. CHRIS KNIGHT | Staff Photographer Facebook Twitter WhatsApp SMS Email Print Copy article link In the long daily grind of a baseball season there are mileposts, good and bad. The Lancaster Stormers had their second bad one in three days Thursday. York’s Jacob Rhinesmith singled home designated runner David Washington on the top of the 12th inning, and the Revolution edged Lancaster, 4-3 before 3,695 at Clipper Magazine Stadium. The Stormers came in having won eight in a row, and come out having lost two of three, both gut-wrenchers, to the team they want and need to beat most. They are now 2-13 on the season against the Revolution. The Stormers hit and pitched well enough in all three games. It was the little things, … They overcame four errors to win Thursday, 4-3. In Tuesday’s game one, Lancaster gave away critical outs on the bases and squandered an elite starting pitching performance by Noah Bremer. That part repeated Thursday. Starter Matt Swarmer got his team into the seventh inning with the lead, allowed one earned run and struck out 13, tying a club record for Ks in a game also shared by Eric Junge (2010) and Bryan Evans (2016). Swarmer, a Governor Mifflin High School and Kuztown University product, pitched 34 innings for the Chicago Cubs in 2022. This season, he has struck out 23 in his last 13 and two-thirds innings. York whiffed 18 times Thursdays against six Lancaster pitchers. And won anyway. Isan Diaz’ two-run homer in the fifth gave the Stormers a 2-0 lead. York tied it with single runs in the sixth (two singles and a sac fly) and seventh (a seeing-eye RBI single by Alfredo Reyes on Swarmer’s last pitch of the night. The Revs went to the ninth inning with the lead thanks mostly to three wild pitches, the second of which bounced and spun to rest no more than five feet from the plate. It allowed speedy York leadoff man Rudy Martin, who had walked and stole second, to fly home safe on a close play. Drama was coming. Lancaster’s Joe Carpenter erased that deficit and ignited the crowd with a solo homer to right center with one out in the ninth. Both bullpens made big pitehes to drag the game wo the 12th, in which Rhinesmith delivered the game-winner, an opposite-field liner to left. The Stormers are still in first place in the Atlantic League’s North Division, two games ahead of York, which won the first half Lancaster now hits the road for a nine-game swing through the New York City metroplex, starting with a weekend three-game series at Long Island. Lefty Brady Tedesco (0-2) gets the start on the mound Friday. Newsletter Success! An email has been sent to with a link to confirm list signup. Error! There was an error processing your request.
